notes.title: Categorical Syllogisms: structures, rules & distribution
notes.content: Master standard-form syllogisms (AAA, EAE, etc.), term distribution, and Venn-diagram testing. Typical CSS prompts ask to define syllogism, state validity rules, or generate syllogisms with universal conclusions.
keyTakeaways: Six classic rules (e.g., undistributed middle, illicit process) determine validity.
Diagramming helps quickly test conclusions for Part-II.
Link to MCQs: mood/figure, distribution, and immediate inferences.

resources.title: forall x: Calgary (free logic textbook) – Categorical logic, proofs
resources.description: Open Logic Project; chapters on arguments, truth tables, proofs

notes.title: Propositions, Connectives & Truth Tables
notes.content: Differentiate simple vs compound propositions and formal symbols (¬, ∧, ∨, →, ↔); construct complete/partial truth tables; identify tautology/contradiction/contingent forms.
keyTakeaways: Truth-functional analysis underpins MCQs on validity.
Characteristic truth tables and equivalence laws speed up proofs.
Practice symbolization from English into TFL.

resources.title: forall x: Calgary – Truth tables & equivalences
Khan Academy LSAT Logic articles (intro to arguments)

notes.title: Rules of Inference & Replacement (Natural Deduction)
notes.content: Know core inference rules (MP, MT, HS, DS, Conj./Add.) and replacement laws (De Morgan, Contraposition, Distribution, Double Negation) for formal proofs.
keyTakeaways: Proof strategies: conditional proof, indirect proof, subproof nesting.
Memorize a compact law list for timed derivations.
CSS often asks 'Explain rules of replacement briefly' or complete multi-step proofs.

resources.title: Stanford Intro to Logic – Exercises
resources.description: Problem sets for propositional & predicate logic

notes.title: Definitions, Ambiguity & Emotive Language
notes.content: Define ambiguity, vagueness, and emotive terms; types of definitions (lexical, stipulative, precising, theoretical, persuasive). Connect to fallacies of ambiguity (equivocation, amphiboly, composition/division).
keyTakeaways: Clear definitions reduce fallacies; show with everyday examples.
Exam often asks to 'discuss types of definitions' or 'emotive language impedes clear thinking'.
Practice refining slippery terms in political/moral debates.

resources.title: OpenStax Introduction to Philosophy – Logic unit

notes.title: Induction, Probability & Mill's Methods
notes.content: Contrast deductive vs inductive support; study Hume's problem of induction; learn Mill's four/five methods (Agreement, Difference, Joint, Residues, Concomitant Variation) for causal discovery.
keyTakeaways: Inductive arguments amplify; cannot be truth-preserving.
Mill's methods are exam favorites—state and illustrate with real cases.
Probability is not identical to inductive logic but formalizes uncertainty.

resources.title: SEP — John Stuart Mill (sections on induction)

notes.title: Scientific Explanation: Hempel's DN model & beyond
notes.content: Cover Hempel's deductive–nomological and statistical models, critiques (counterexamples, ceteris paribus laws), and newer views (causal–mechanistic, unification).
keyTakeaways: DN ties explanation to logical entailment from laws + conditions.
Limitations: relevance, probabilistic cases, historical explanations.
Use examples from physics and history for contrast.

notes.title: Hypothesis & Scientific Method
notes.content: Define hypothesis, role in discovery/justification, falsifiability and testing, distinction between scientific and unscientific explanation.
keyTakeaways: Hypotheses must be testable (operationalized) and risk refutation.
Differentiate context of discovery vs justification in essays.
Use case studies to show predictive novelty.

notes.title: Descartes' Cogito: certainty & critiques
notes.content: Explain 'cogito, ergo sum' as foundational certainty; clarify performance/first-person character; survey critiques (circularity, reliance on clarity & distinction).
keyTakeaways: Cogito resists hyperbolic doubt as self-verifying thought act.
Debate: Is 'therefore' inferential or immediate awareness?
Connect to influence on rationalism and modern epistemology.

notes.title: Berkeley's Idealism — 'Esse est percipi'
notes.content: Present subjective idealism: existence of sensible objects depends on perception; God's perception sustains continuity; contrast with representational realism.
keyTakeaways: Rejects matter as unknowable substratum.
Addresses persistence via divine perception.
Exam often asks for critical exposition of 'To be is to be perceived'.

notes.title: Leibniz's Monadology & Pre-established Harmony
notes.content: Explain monads as simple, non-extended substances; perception/appetition; no causal interaction between mind and body—only harmony coordinated by God.
keyTakeaways: Truth as conceptual containment informs necessity/contingency.
Monads 'mirror' the universe from unique perspectives.
Compare with occasionalism and interactionism.

notes.title: Kant's Ethics — Categorical Imperative
notes.content: Duty for duty's sake; maxims tested by universalizability and respect for persons (humanity as an end).
keyTakeaways: Contrast with consequentialism (intentions vs outcomes).
Formulations: Universal Law, Humanity, Kingdom of Ends.
Apply to exam scenarios (lying promise, beneficence).

notes.title: Utilitarianism & Virtue Ethics (contrast)
notes.content: Utilitarian calculus (act vs rule); Aristotle's virtue ethics (eudaimonia, doctrine of the mean).
keyTakeaways: Use trolley-type cases to compare frameworks.
Virtue focuses on character & habituation, not rules/outcomes alone.
CSS short notes often include 'Utilitarianism' or 'Virtue ethics'.

notes.title: Rawls's Justice & the Difference Principle
notes.content: Original Position & Veil of Ignorance; two principles of justice; focus on fair equality of opportunity and permissible inequalities that benefit the least advantaged.
keyTakeaways: Contrast with utilitarian aggregation.
Debates on limits of the difference principle appear in CSS.
Relate to contemporary policy examples.

notes.title: Foucault's Power/Knowledge
notes.content: Power and knowledge are mutually constitutive; discourses produce subjects and normalize practices (e.g., prisons, clinics).
keyTakeaways: Opposes 'knowledge is power' as mere instrument; shows co-production.
Use genealogy to trace historical formations.
Likely essay: distinguish Foucault from Baconian slogan.

notes.title: Dialectical & Historical Materialism (Marx, Engels)
notes.content: Material conditions shape social forms and consciousness; history as class struggle; dialectics reworked from Hegel to materialist analysis.
keyTakeaways: Explain base/superstructure with examples (law, culture).
Avoid caricatures; note later Analytical Marxism revisions.
CSS often contrasts with Kant/Hegel or liberal theories.

notes.title: Pragmatism (Peirce–James–Dewey) & relevance
notes.content: Truth as what works in practice; meaning via practical consequences; method over metaphysical fixations; connects to contemporary pragmatism/neo-pragmatism.
keyTakeaways: Use James's pragmatic method in exam essays.
Show differences from instrumentalism and verificationism.
Relate to scientific inquiry and democracy (Dewey).

notes.title: Logical Positivism & A.J. Ayer's Verification Principle
notes.content: Meaning tied to verification (analytic vs empirical); metaphysical statements deemed nonsensical; know weak vs strong verification and criticisms.
keyTakeaways: Clarify how ethics/aesthetics fare under verificationism.
Explain why the principle itself struggles with self-verification.
Use concise examples (e.g., 'the Absolute is pure Being').

notes.title: Al-Ghazālī vs the Philosophers; Journey to Mysticism
notes.content: Ghazālī's critique of falāsifa (causality, eternity of world) and turn from kalām/philosophy to Sufism; limits of reason and role of experiential knowledge.
keyTakeaways: Understand 'Tahāfut al-Falāsifa' theses and causation critique.
Connect to CSS prompts on Ghazālī's intellectual journey.
Contrast with Ibn Rushd's defense of philosophy.

notes.title: Ibn Rushd (Averroes): Reconciliation of Philosophy & Religion
notes.content: Harmonization thesis: demonstrative philosophy and revealed law address different audiences; allegorical interpretation permissible for the learned.
keyTakeaways: Use 'Decisive Treatise' to frame reconciliation.
Distinguish types of reasoning: dialectical, rhetorical, demonstrative.
Contrast with Ghazālī on causality and eternity.

notes.title: Ibn Khaldūn's ʿAṣabiyya & Philosophy of History; Iqbal & Sir Syed (modern)
notes.content: Ibn Khaldūn's Muqaddimah: ʿasabiyya, rise/decline cycles; Iqbal's Khudi & principle of movement (ijtihād); Sir Syed's rationalist educational reforms.
keyTakeaways: Use ʿasabiyya to analyze state formation and decline.
Iqbal: dynamic selfhood & reconstruction of religious thought.
Sir Syed: rationalism, modern education, nature doctrine.

resources.title: Paper on Sir Syed Ahmad Khan's philosophy (PDF)

fpsc_papers_and_syllabus.title: CSS Syllabus (3rd-party mirror; includes reading list)
